com.hps.wizard
Class StateFragment

java.lang.Object
  android.support.v4.app.Fragment
      com.hps.wizard.StateFragment
All Implemented Interfaces:
ComponentCallbacks, View.OnCreateContextMenuListener
public abstract class StateFragment
extends Fragment

This class acts as the parent class for all states.

Nested Class Summary
static class StateFragment.StateDefinition
          The definition of a state, including its class and arguments.

Constructor Detail

StateFragment

public StateFragment()
Method Detail

canGoForward

protected boolean canGoForward()

Called to make sure a next click should be honored. Any form validation should go here.

The default implementation simply returns true.

Returns:
true if this state can move forward, false otherwise.

getBundleToSave

protected Bundle getBundleToSave()
Get the bundle to use in {getSavedInstanceState(). This is not necessary, but it will ensure that the bundle contains all of the arguments which were originally given to the fragment at instantiation.

Returns:
The fragment's arguments or an empty bundle if they were null.

getFinalResult

public Intent getFinalResult()
If this is the final state, this method will be called to retrieve the intent that should be passed to Activity.setResult(int, Intent). It can be null if there is no need to tell the original activity anything about this wizard.

Returns:
The intent, or null if none is needed.

getNeutralButtonLabel

public String getNeutralButtonLabel()

Gets the label for the button. Override this method to make it appear.

Returns:
The label to put on the neutral button. Returning null hides the button.

getNextButtonLabel

public String getNextButtonLabel()

Gets the label for the button.

The default implementation returns R.string.wizard_next or R.string.wizard_finish if isFinal() returns true.

Returns:
The label to put on the next button. Returning null hides the button.

getNextState

public abstract StateFragment.StateDefinition getNextState()
Assuming there is a next state, this method is called to return the class of that state. It must not be null and must extend StateFragment. If there is no next state, canGoForward should return false.

Returns:
the StateFragment.StateDefinition for the next state.

getPreviousButtonLabel

public String getPreviousButtonLabel()

Gets the label for the button. Override this method to make it appear.

Returns:
The label to put on the previous button. Returning null hides the button.

getSavedInstanceState

public Bundle getSavedInstanceState()

Called when the StateFragment should save it's current state. The bundle returned will be passed to Fragment.instantiate(android.content.Context, String, Bundle) if this StateFragment is recreated.

The default implementation simply returns null. Override this if there is any information that should survive the wizard activity being destroyed and recreated.

Returns:
the bundle of data, which can be null.

getTitle

public String getTitle()

Gets the title for this view. Override this method to place a title on a step.

Giving a null title will hide the title view. Giving empty titles in some steps and non-empty ones in others could result in the content area seeming to bounce around and thus should be avoided.

Returns:
the title, or null to hide the space which is otherwise reserved for it.

getWizardActivity

protected AbstractWizardActivity getWizardActivity()
Returns:
the AbstractWizardActivity that was set in create(AbstractWizardActivity, String, Bundle).

isFinal

protected boolean isFinal()

Returns true if this is the last state.

The default implementation returns false. Override this if the state is the last one in the wizard. If it's the last state it's Next button will be replaced by a finish button. The visibility of the previous button still depends on getPreviousButtonLabel().

Returns:
true if this is the last state, false otherwise.

onAdded

public void onAdded()

Called when the state has been added to the wizard. At this point the activity and wizard will both be available and any view setup can be performed.

The default implementation does nothing.

onBack

public void onBack()

Called when the state is moving back to the previous state. This is a good place to save off anything that needs to survive the lifetime of the wizard.

The default implementation does nothing.

onForward

public void onForward()

Called when the state is moving forward to the next state. This is a good place to save off anything that needs to survive the lifetime of the wizard.

The default implementation does nothing.

onNeutralButtonClicked

public void onNeutralButtonClicked()

Called when the neutral button is clicked.

The default implementation throws an exception. If you're going to add a neutral button you've got to override this and handle its clicks.

validate

public boolean validate()

Perform any necessary validation prior to moving on.

The default implementation always returns true.

Returns:
true if the state is valid and we can keep going, false otherwise.

shouldValidateInBackground

public boolean shouldValidateInBackground()

Determines whether to perform validation on the main thread or on a background thread. If the validation is done on a background thread, validate() will not be called. Instead, getValidatorTask() will be used to retrieve the ValidationAsyncTask for the AbstractWizardActivity to run.

The framework handles all background processing and will display an indeterminate progress bar which can be updated. See ValidationAsyncTask and TaskFragment for more.

Note: If validation includes network activity newer versions of Android will throw an exception if that activity occurs on the UI thread. Therefore, any validation against a server should always be done on the background.

The default implementation always returns false.

Returns:
true if validation should be performed on the background thread, false if it belongs on the UI thread.

getValidatorTask

public ValidationAsyncTask getValidatorTask()

Get the ValidationAsyncTask to use when validating this state in the background.

The default implementation uses foreground validation and therefore returns null.

Returns:
the task, or null if this state is validated in the foreground.
